articles.title: ‘We want to get our lives back,’ Gaza children declare
articles.summary: After two years of war that kept them out of classrooms, Gaza’s children are finally returning to the classroom, surrounded by devastation – but determined to learn.
articles.content:
“What we need now are notebooks, books, and pens. We want to get our lives back”, said one young Palestinian girl, Sham Al-Abd.

She now attends the Deir al-Balah Joint Elementary School run by the UN Palestine refugee agency (UNRWA).

Despite the old furniture and the few drawings that brighten the classroom walls at a school visited by our UN News correspondent, the children’s excitement to return there after months of seeking shelter from the bombs, remains undiminished.

One of Sham’s classmates, Asil Al-Loh, spoke enthusiastically about how she felt: “We want to learn and play, and study all subjects as we did before. Now we only study Arabic, English and mathematics.”

UN News Palestinian student Sham al-Abd at Deir al-Balah Co-educational Primary School, run by UNRWA.

Attempt to restore normalcy

Following the ceasefire in Gaza, UNRWA is working to restore a sense of normalcy in schools that had previously been used as shelters.

Commissioner-General of UNRWA, Philippe Lazzarini, announced that the agency is expanding its “Return to Learning” programme in Gaza, offering both in-person and online education.

At the Deir al-Balah Joint Elementary School, signs of transformation from shelter to school, are still evident. Our correspondent saw families cooking meals in the corridors, while tents still occupy the schoolyard.

When young student Shahd al-Bahisi returned to Deir al-Balah, she said she found the area “destroyed,” and that “many displaced people were still there.”

UN News Students sitting on the floor while attending classes at Deir al-Balah Co-educational Primary School, run by UNRWA.

Despite this, Shahd seems determined to resume her studies.

Some classrooms remain without enough chairs, their floors are covered with tarpaulins and blankets. Yet the excitement and determination are shining through.

A chance at ‘life, dignity and education’

“To date, more than 62,000 students have benefited from temporary learning services through these basic educational activities since their launch on 1 August 2024”, according to Inas Hamdam, UNRWA’s spokesperson.

Deir al-Balah School is one of those converted into a shelter but UNRWA continues to open additional temporary learning spaces, said Ms. Hamdam.

UN News Deir al-Balah Co-educational Primary School, run by UNRWA.

She explained that this is being done in parallel with the provision of distance learning services to approximately 300,000 students in Gaza, adding that: “8,000 teachers are contributing to the provision of these services to the children of Gaza who have suffered the ravages of war”.

She emphasised that children, wherever they may be, “deserve a chance at life, dignity and education”.

Despite the war’s devastation, voices and laughter ring out once again in the hallways of Deir-al-Balah’s school.

articles.reasoning: The article reports on the resumption of education for tens of thousands of children in Gaza after war-related disruptions, highlighting efforts by UNRWA to restore learning opportunities despite challenging conditions. This represents a meaningful positive impact on children's rights to education and dignity in a conflict-affected area, with broad humanitarian significance and detailed context.
articles.personality_title: Children in Gaza return to school despite war damage
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – For two years, children in Gaza were kept out of school because of ongoing war. Many schools were damaged or used as shelters, making it hard for kids to learn.

**What happened** – After a ceasefire, children have started going back to school. At the Deir al-Balah Joint Elementary School, run by the United Nations Relief and Works Agency (UNRWA), students like Sham Al-Abd expressed their eagerness to study again, even though classrooms are still crowded and damaged.

**Impact** – More than 62,000 students have already joined temporary learning programs since August 1, 2024. UNRWA is providing both in-person and online classes, with 8,000 teachers helping children who lost months of education. This effort gives children a chance to regain normal life and dignity despite the difficulties.

**What's next step** – UNRWA plans to open more temporary learning spaces and continue distance education to reach up to 300,000 students. These steps aim to rebuild education and support children’s futures in Gaza.

**One-sentence takeaway** – After years of war, thousands of children in Gaza are returning to school with help from UN programs, bringing hope for a better future through education.
articles.personality_title_fr: Les enfants de Gaza retournent à l’école malgré les dégâts de la guerre
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Pendant deux ans, les enfants de Gaza n’ont pas pu aller à l’école à cause de la guerre. Beaucoup d’écoles ont été endommagées ou transformées en abris, rendant l’apprentissage difficile.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Après un cessez-le-feu, les enfants ont recommencé à aller à l’école. À l’école élémentaire mixte de Deir al-Balah, gérée par l’Agence des Nations Unies pour les réfugiés palestiniens (UNRWA), des élèves comme Sham Al-Abd ont exprimé leur envie d’étudier, même si les salles de classe restent surpeuplées et abîmées.

**Impact** – Plus de 62 000 élèves ont déjà rejoint des programmes d’apprentissage temporaires depuis le 1er août 2024. L’UNRWA propose des cours en présentiel et en ligne, avec 8 000 enseignants qui aident les enfants ayant perdu plusieurs mois d’école. Cet effort permet aux enfants de retrouver une vie normale et leur dignité malgré les difficultés.

**Prochaine étape** – L’UNRWA prévoit d’ouvrir plus d’espaces d’apprentissage temporaires et de poursuivre l’éducation à distance pour atteindre jusqu’à 300 000 élèves. Ces mesures visent à reconstruire l’éducation et soutenir l’avenir des enfants à Gaza.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Après des années de guerre, des milliers d’enfants à Gaza retournent à l’école grâce aux programmes de l’ONU, offrant un espoir d’avenir meilleur par l’éducation.
articles.personality_title_es: Niños de Gaza regresan a la escuela a pesar de los daños de la guerra
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Durante dos años, los niños en Gaza no pudieron ir a la escuela debido a la guerra. Muchas escuelas quedaron dañadas o se usaron como refugios, dificultando el aprendizaje.

**Qué pasó** – Tras un alto el fuego, los niños han comenzado a regresar a la escuela. En la Escuela Primaria Mixta Deir al-Balah, administrada por la Agencia de Naciones Unidas para los Refugiados Palestinos (UNRWA), estudiantes como Sham Al-Abd mostraron entusiasmo por volver a estudiar, aunque las aulas aún están llenas y dañadas.

**Impacto** – Más de 62,000 estudiantes ya participan en programas temporales de aprendizaje desde el 1 de agosto de 2024. La UNRWA ofrece clases presenciales y en línea, con 8,000 maestros apoyando a niños que perdieron meses de educación. Este esfuerzo da a los niños la oportunidad de recuperar una vida normal y dignidad a pesar de las dificultades.

**Próximo paso** – La UNRWA planea abrir más espacios temporales de aprendizaje y continuar la educación a distancia para llegar hasta 300,000 estudiantes. Estas acciones buscan reconstruir la educación y apoyar el futuro de los niños en Gaza.

**Frase clave** – Después de años de guerra, miles de niños en Gaza regresan a la escuela con ayuda de programas de la ONU, ofreciendo esperanza para un futuro mejor a través de la educación.
